item.title: Study Week May 29 – June 4
item.description:
🎤 Week 5: Presentation and Communication Skills

This week focused on how to effectively communicate ideas. We practiced creating visually clean and logical presentations and worked on public speaking skills.
We prepared slide decks on academic project topics and presented them to each other.

🗣 We also practiced the “elevator pitch” technique — summarizing a project in just 30 seconds.
✨ A valuable skill: the ability to highlight the main point and present it with confidence.

🎯 Week’s takeaway: a great presentation isn’t just about the slides — it’s about the energy behind your words.

item.title: Study Week May 22–28
item.description:
🐍 Week 4: Writing the First Python Program

This week we began exploring the Python programming language. We wrote our first scripts, solved problems using conditionals, loops, and lists,
and learned how to automate working with text and spreadsheets.

In practice, we built a mini calculator and a simple CSV data analyzer.
🔥 The most exciting part: a project that counts word frequency in a text.

💡 Realization of the week: programming isn’t hard if you break problems down into small steps.

item.title: Study Week May 15–21
item.description:
📋 Week 3: Fundamentals of Project Management

This week we explored the core principles of project management: the project life cycle, participant roles, goals, and risk assessment.
We reviewed IT case studies, discussed Agile vs. Waterfall approaches, and built a Gantt chart for a hypothetical startup.

🗂 During the seminar, we worked in teams to simulate launching an online store — assigning roles, setting deadlines, and identifying risks.
🔍 Lesson of the week: even the best idea can fail without a solid plan.

item.title: Academic Website with Hugo Academic
item.description:
🌐 Academic Website with Hugo Academic: A Platform That Works for You

Today, having an online presence is becoming an essential part of academic and educational careers. Publications, projects, talks, and achievements deserve to be collected in one place — as a personal website. One of the most convenient and flexible solutions for this is Hugo Academic.

🧠 What Is Hugo Academic?

Hugo Academic is a theme template for static websites, built on the Hugo framework. It’s specifically designed for researchers, educators, and students who want to professionally showcase their research, courses, biography, and publications.

The website is built as a collection of text files (in Markdown format) and can be deployed on any hosting platform — GitHub Pages, Netlify, Vercel, and others.

📚 What Can You Include on Your Website?

  • Biography and photo
  • List of publications with links
  • Courses you teach
  • Research projects and grants
  • Presentations, talks, and videos
  • Blog or news section
  • Resume (including a downloadable PDF)
  • Languages, skills, interests, and contact details

⚙️ Why Choose Hugo Academic?

  • 🛠 Automation: Integrate with Google Scholar, ORCID, BibTeX files, and publication RSS feeds
  • 📈 SEO & Speed: Lightning-fast load times, even with a weak connection
  • 🎨 Minimalist & Stylish: A clean academic look that’s also modern and responsive
  • 🧩 Extensible: Add new sections, integrations, and features with ease
  • 💻 Full Content Control: You’re not dependent on third-party platforms
  • 🌍 Multilingual Support: Easily build a multilingual site

🔄 How Is the Site Structured?

The website structure consists of folders:

  • content/ — pages such as bio, projects, publications, and blog posts
  • data/ — structured data like skills, interests, and profiles
  • assets/ — images and media files
  • config/ — site configuration and settings
  • themes/ — contains the Academic theme itself

You write your content in Markdown, and Hugo automatically renders it to HTML, generating a complete website.

🚀 Deploy in 15 Minutes

  1. Install Hugo and download the Academic theme
  2. Fill in your personal details
  3. Write your posts and pages in Markdown
  4. Push your site to GitHub and publish via Netlify or Vercel

The site updates automatically with every change, making it convenient even for beginners.

🔍 Who Is It For?

  • Students and graduate students who want to showcase their work
  • Lecturers building a professional teaching portfolio
  • Researchers with publications and ongoing projects
  • Academic job applicants building a public academic profile

🎓 Conclusion

A site built with Hugo Academic is more than just a digital business card — it’s a professional platform that reflects your journey in science, education, and beyond. It highlights your identity, organizes your achievements, and makes your work accessible to colleagues, students, and the wider academic community.

If you haven’t created your personal site yet — now might be the time to start. Hugo Academic gives you a simple yet powerful tool to present yourself in the digital world of academia. 🌍

item.title: Study Week May 8–14
item.description:
🗃 Week 2: Diving into SQL

This week we started learning SQL — the language used for querying databases. We covered essential operators: SELECT, WHERE, ORDER BY, GROUP BY, and JOIN.

In the lab, we wrote queries for a sample customer and orders database. It was especially interesting to filter data using conditions and combine tables with joins.

💪 Task of the week: find all customers who placed orders worth more than 5,000 rubles.
🧠 Insight of the week: SQL is a powerful tool, and writing queries feels like composing logical expressions.

item.title: Study Week May 1–7
item.description:
📚 Week 1: First Steps in Data Analysis

This week we began exploring the basics of data analysis. We learned how to work with spreadsheets in Excel, how to build charts, and how to use functions like VLOOKUP, IF, and pivot tables.
During the practical sessions, we also tried simple data visualizations in Google Sheets and analyzed a small retail sales dataset.

✨ Highlight of the week: we explored a case study on detecting anomalies in retail reports.
📌 Takeaway: data is not just numbers — it’s the foundation for decision-making.
